verses.verse: (Gideon’s Ephod) Then the men of Israel said to Gideon, ((Judg. 9:8)) “Rule over us, both you and your son, and your grandson also; for you have (Judg. 3:9; 9:17) delivered us from the hand of Midian.”
But Gideon said to them, “I will not rule over you, nor shall my son rule over you; (1 Sam. 8:7; 10:19; 12:12; Ps. 10:16) the LORD shall rule over you.”

Then Gideon said to them, “I would like to make a request of you, that each of you would give me the earrings from his plunder.” For they had golden earrings, (Gen. 37:25, 28) because they were Ishmaelites.
So they answered, “We will gladly give them.” And they spread out a garment, and each man threw into it the earrings from his plunder.

Now the weight of the gold earrings that he requested was one thousand seven hundred shekels of gold, besides the crescent ornaments, pendants, and purple robes which were on the kings of Midian, and besides the chains that were around their camels’ necks.

Then Gideon (Judg. 17:5) made it into an ephod and set it up in his city, (Judg. 6:11, 24) Ophrah. And all Israel ((Ps. 106:39)) played the harlot with it there. It became (Deut. 7:16) a snare to Gideon and to his house.
Thus Midian was subdued before the children of Israel, so that they lifted their heads no more. (Judg. 5:31) And the country was quiet for forty years in the days of Gideon.
(Death of Gideon) Then (Judg. 6:32; 7:1) Jerubbaal the son of Joash went and dwelt in his own house.
Gideon had (Judg. 9:2, 5) seventy sons who were his own offspring, for he had many wives.
(Judg. 9:1) And his concubine who was in Shechem also bore him a son, whose name he called Abimelech.
Now Gideon the son of Joash died (Gen. 25:8; Job 5:26) at a good old age, and was buried in the tomb of Joash his father, (Judg. 6:24; 8:27) in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
So it was, (Judg. 2:19) as soon as Gideon was dead, that the children of Israel again (Judg. 2:17) played the harlot with the Baals, (Judg. 9:4, 46) and made Baal-Berith their god.
Thus the children of Israel (Deut. 4:9; Judg. 3:7; Ps. 78:11, 42; 106:13, 21) did not remember the LORD their God, who had delivered them from the hands of all their enemies on every side;
(Judg. 9:16-18) nor did they show kindness to the house of Jerubbaal (Gideon) in accordance with the good he had done for Israel.

(Abimelech’s Conspiracy) Then Abimelech the son of Jerubbaal went to Shechem, to (Judg. 8:31, 35) his mother’s brothers, and spoke with them and with all the family of the house of his mother’s father, saying,

“Please speak in the hearing of all the men of Shechem: ‘Which is better for you, that all (Judg. 8:30; 9:5, 18) seventy of the sons of Jerubbaal reign over you, or that one reign over you?’ Remember that I am your own flesh and (Gen. 29:14) bone.”

And his mother’s brothers spoke all these words concerning him in the hearing of all the men of Shechem; and their heart was inclined to follow Abimelech, for they said, “He is our (Gen. 29:15) brother.”

So they gave him seventy shekels of silver from the temple of (Judg. 8:33) Baal-Berith, with which Abimelech hired (Judg. 11:3; 2 Chr. 13:7; Acts 17:5) worthless and reckless men; and they followed him.

Then he went to his father’s house (Judg. 6:24) at Ophrah and (Judg. 8:30; 9:2, 18; 2 Kin. 11:1, 2) killed his brothers, the seventy sons of Jerubbaal, on one stone. But Jotham the youngest son of Jerubbaal was left, because he hid himself.
And all the men of Shechem gathered together, all of Beth Millo, and they went and made Abimelech king beside the terebinth tree at the pillar that was in Shechem.

(The Parable of the Trees) Now when they told Jotham, he went and stood on top of (Deut. 11:29; 27:12; Josh. 8:33; John 4:20) Mount Gerizim, and lifted his voice and cried out. And he said to them: “Listen to me, you men of Shechem, That God may listen to you!
“The (2 Kin. 14:9) trees once went forth to anoint a king over them. And they said to the olive tree, (Judg. 8:22, 23) ‘Reign over us!’
But the olive tree said to them, ‘Should I cease giving my oil, ((John 5:23)) With which they honor God and men, And go to sway over trees?’
“Then the trees said to the fig tree, ‘You come and reign over us!’
But the fig tree said to them, ‘Should I cease my sweetness and my good fruit, And go to sway over trees?’
“Then the trees said to the vine, ‘You come and reign over us!’
But the vine said to them, ‘Should I cease my new wine, (Ps. 104:15) Which cheers both God and men, And go to sway over trees?’
“Then all the trees said to the bramble, ‘You come and reign over us!’

And the bramble said to the trees, ‘If in truth you anoint me as king over you, Then come and take shelter in my (Is. 30:2; Dan. 4:12; Hos. 14:7) shade; But if not, (Num. 21:28; Judg. 9:20; Ezek. 19:14) let fire come out of the bramble And devour the (2 Kin. 14:9; Is. 2:13; Ezek. 31:3) cedars of Lebanon!’
“Now therefore, if you have acted in truth and sincerity in making Abimelech king, and if you have dealt well with Jerubbaal and his house, and have done to him (Judg. 8:35) as he deserves—
for my (Judg. 7) father fought for you, risked his life, and (Judg. 8:22) delivered you out of the hand of Midian;

(Judg. 8:30, 35; 9:2, 5, 6) but you have risen up against my father’s house this day, and killed his seventy sons on one stone, and made Abimelech, the son of his (Judg. 8:31) female servant, king over the men of Shechem, because he is your brother—
if then you have acted in truth and sincerity with Jerubbaal and with his house this day, then (Is. 8:6; (Phil. 3:3)) rejoice in Abimelech, and let him also rejoice in you.
“But if not, (Judg. 9:15, 45, 56, 57) let fire come from Abimelech and devour the men of Shechem and Beth Millo; and let fire come from the men of Shechem and from Beth Millo and devour Abimelech!”
And Jotham ran away and fled; and he went to (Num. 21:16) Beer and dwelt there, for fear of Abimelech his brother.
(Downfall of Abimelech) After Abimelech had reigned over Israel three years,

(1 Kin. 12:15; Is. 19:14) God sent a (1 Sam. 16:14; 18:9, 10; 1 Kin. 22:22; 2 Chr. 18:22) spirit of ill will between Abimelech and the men of Shechem; and the men of Shechem (Is. 33:1) dealt treacherously with Abimelech,

(1 Kin. 2:32; Esth. 9:25; Matt. 23:35, 36) that the crime done to the seventy sons of Jerubbaal might be settled and their (Num. 35:33) blood be laid on Abimelech their brother, who killed them, and on the men of Shechem, who aided him in the killing of his brothers.
And the men of Shechem set men in ambush against him on the tops of the mountains, and they robbed all who passed by them along that way; and it was told Abimelech.
Now Gaal the son of Ebed came with his brothers and went over to Shechem; and the men of Shechem put their confidence in him.

So they went out into the fields, and gathered grapes from their vineyards and trod them, and made merry. And they went into (Judg. 9:4) the house of their god, and ate and drank, and cursed Abimelech.

Then Gaal the son of Ebed said, (1 Sam. 25:10; 1 Kin. 12:16) “Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him? Is he not the son of Jerubbaal, and is not Zebul his officer? Serve the men of (Gen. 34:2, 6; Josh. 24:32) Hamor the father of Shechem; but why should we serve him?
(2 Sam. 15:4) If only this people were under my authority! Then I would remove Abimelech.” So he said to Abimelech, “Increase your army and come out!”
When Zebul, the ruler of the city, heard the words of Gaal the son of Ebed, his anger was aroused.
And he sent messengers to Abimelech secretly, saying, “Take note! Gaal the son of Ebed and his brothers have come to Shechem; and here they are, fortifying the city against you.
Now therefore, get up by night, you and the people who are with you, and lie in wait in the field.

And it shall be, as soon as the sun is up in the morning, that you shall rise early and rush upon the city; and when he and the people who are with him come out against you, you may then do to them as you find opportunity.”
So Abimelech and all the people who were with him rose by night, and lay in wait against Shechem in four companies.
When Gaal the son of Ebed went out and stood in the entrance to the city gate, Abimelech and the people who were with him rose from lying in wait.
And when Gaal saw the people, he said to Zebul, “Look, people are coming down from the tops of the mountains!” But Zebul said to him, “You see the shadows of the mountains as if they were men.”
So Gaal spoke again and said, “See, people are coming down from the center of the land, and another company is coming from the Diviners’ Terebinth Tree.”

Then Zebul said to him, “Where indeed is your mouth now, with which you (Judg. 9:28, 29) said, ‘Who is Abimelech, that we should serve him?’ Are not these the people whom you despised? Go out, if you will, and fight with them now.”
So Gaal went out, leading the men of Shechem, and fought with Abimelech.
And Abimelech chased him, and he fled from him; and many fell wounded, to the very entrance of the gate.
Then Abimelech dwelt at Arumah, and Zebul drove out Gaal and his brothers, so that they would not dwell in Shechem.
And it came about on the next day that the people went out into the field, and they told Abimelech.
So he took his people, divided them into three companies, and lay in wait in the field. And he looked, and there were the people, coming out of the city; and he rose against them and attacked them.
